Posted By: Taudisban (9/17/2013 11:05:44 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
You know what makes black interesting with this? Sacrifice effects. You can turn him off of creature status by saccing something else. If you play this little balancing act he should be nigh impossible to get rid of.  
  
If using in Legacy, the immediate Go-to would be The Gate; where you go from [Gatekeeper of Malakir](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gatekeeper of Malakir), into [Nighthawk](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Nighthawk), and boom. You can also wait to drop another critter until it's time to attack in order to give him psuedo-haste or get the chance to see their hand with discard spells.
posts.html:
You know what makes black interesting with this? Sacrifice effects. You can turn him off of creature status by saccing something else. If you play this little balancing act he should be nigh impossible to get rid of.

If using in Legacy, the immediate Go-to would be The Gate; where you go from Gatekeeper of Malakir, into Nighthawk, and boom. You can also wait to drop another critter until it's time to attack in order to give him psuedo-haste or get the chance to see their hand with discard spells.

Posted By: NARFNra (9/17/2013 9:01:47 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Possibly the most powerful of the 5 gods. Both of his signature abilities can be game-changing, even in decks not built around him.   
  
Preventing your opponents from gaining life is one thing - it shuts down life gain and a few other shenanigans like [exquisite blood](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=exquisite blood) + [sanguine bond](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=sanguine bond), or life changers like [invincible hymn](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=invincible hymn), [tree of redemption](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=tree of redemption), and [eternity vessel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=eternity vessel). But being able to draw cards by paying life is another entirely! I can very easily see this being banned in Commander and Modern.   
  
I imagine most black mages are going to be using Erebus to counter [Sphinx's Revelation](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sphinx's Revelation).
posts.html:
Possibly the most powerful of the 5 gods. Both of his signature abilities can be game-changing, even in decks not built around him.

Preventing your opponents from gaining life is one thing - it shuts down life gain and a few other shenanigans like exquisite blood + sanguine bond, or life changers like invincible hymn, tree of redemption, and eternity vessel. But being able to draw cards by paying life is another entirely! I can very easily see this being banned in Commander and Modern.

I imagine most black mages are going to be using Erebus to counter Sphinx's Revelation.

posts.post_content: @kinghydra510 Let's Assume it is standard and your opponent cast [Chained to the Rocks](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Chained to the Rocks) and targets Erebos and you cast Hero's Downfall targeting let's say [Gray Merchant of Asphodel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gray Merchant of Asphodel) the Merchant will die, the game will check to see if anything changes it will notice that Erebos is no longer a creature and Chained to the Rocks effect will fizzle seeing it now has no legal target and it will just sit there forever(if it was a [Path to Exile](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Path to Exile) i would just fizzle and go to the graveyard. I might not have used the correct terms for certain things but that is what would happen.
posts.html:

Posted By: sceadu (9/23/2013 6:48:49 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
@kinghydra510  
  
Pretty sure you have it right. As soon as your devotion goes below 5, Erebos becomes an enchantment as a state based effect. So your kill makes him no longer a creature, the exile has no valid target and therefore fizzles.
posts.html:
@kinghydra510

Pretty sure you have it right. As soon as your devotion goes below 5, Erebos becomes an enchantment as a state based effect. So your kill makes him no longer a creature, the exile has no valid target and therefore fizzles.

posts.post_content:
I remember reading comments about this, where people said he's the best god, but I wouldn't think so. Not allowing opponents to gain life is more of a niche ability. People didn't play [Thragtusk](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Thragtusk) just because you gained life. It was certainly nice it came with it, though.  
  
Drawing a card for ![1](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=1&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol) is very good. That being said, did [Bloodgift Demon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bloodgift Demon) get much Standard play? He's a more consistent, less blockable card drawer than this. I'd think Standard players would rather have consistent moderate success than inconsistent exceptional success. I could be wrong about this, though.  
  
I think he is very good as a god, and certainly among the top three. I just don't think he'll see too much main-deck standard play.
posts.html:

I'd think Standard players would rather have consistent moderate success than inconsistent exceptional success. I could be wrong about this, though.

I think he is very good as a god, and certainly among the top three. I just don't think he'll see too much main-deck standard play.
